revision.text:
{{for|the British businesswoman|Carol Kane (businesswoman)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Carol Kane | image = [[File:Carol Kane Gene Wilder 1977.jpg|220px]] | caption = Carol Kane and [[Gene Wilder]] in a publicity photo for ''[[The World's Greatest Lover]]'', 1977 | imagesize = Kane in ''[[The World's Greatest Lover]]'' (1977) | birth_name = Carolyn Laurie Kane | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|06|18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/artist/carol-kane-p36788|title=Carol Kane movies, photos, movie reviews, filmography, and biography - AllMovie|work=[[AllMovie]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|accessdate=March 22, 2015}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Actress, comedian | years_active = 1966–present }} '''Carolyn Laurie Kane''' (born June 18, 1952) is an [[Americans|America]]n stage, screen and television [[actor|actress]] and comedian. She became known in the 1970s in films such as ''[[Hester Street (film)|Hester Street]]'' (for which she received an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nomination) and ''[[Annie Hall]]''. She appeared on the television series ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' in the early 1980s, as Simka Gravas, the wife of [[Latka Gravas|Latka]], the character played by [[Andy Kaufman]], winning two [[Emmy Award]]s for her work. She has played the character of [[Madame Morrible]] in the musical ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', both in regional productions and on Broadway from 2005 to 2014. Since 2015, she has been a main cast member on the [[Netflix]] original series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'', in which she plays Lillian Kaushtupper. == Early life == Kane was born in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], the daughter of Joy, a [[jazz]] singer, teacher, dancer, and pianist, and Michael Kane, an architect who worked for the [[World Bank]].[http://www.filmreference.com/film/77/Carol-Kane.html "Carol Kane Biography (1952–)"] filmreference.com. Retrieved August 27, 2011. Her family is [[Jewish]], and her grandparents emigrated from Russia.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070320084513/http://www.open.org/glennab/carolkanefanbio.htm "Carol Kane Unofficial Fan Page" at the Wayback Machine] Her parents divorced when she was 12 years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.open.org/glennab/cktvguidemay1983.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 27, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230511/http://www.open.org/glennab/cktvguidemay1983.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy }} She attended the Cherry Lawn School, a progressive boarding school in [[Darien, Connecticut]], until 1965.[http://www.cherrylawnschool.org/directory/class/clstbl65.html "Cherry Lawn School, Class of 1965"] CherryLawnSchool.org. Retrieved August 27, 2011.[http://www.cherrylawnschool.org/pom/photomonth199910.html "Cherry Lawn School Photo Of The Month, October 1999"] CherryLawnSchool.org. Retrieved August 27, 2011. She also went to the [[Professional Children's School]], in New York City, and made her professional theatre debut in a 1966 production of ''[[The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (novel)|The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie]]'', starring [[Tammy Grimes]].[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800020210/bio "Carol Kane Biography"] YahooMovies. Retrieved August 27, 2011. == Career == ===Television=== Kane portrayed Simka Dahblitz-Gravas, wife of Latka Gravas ([[Andy Kaufman]]), on the American television series ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'', from 1981–83. She earned two [[Emmy Award]]s for her work in the series.{{cite news|last1=Lacher|first1=Irene|title=Moving a Step Beyond|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/11/entertainment/et-lacher11|accessdate=January 28, 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=May 11, 2002}} In 1984, Kane appeared in episode 12, season 3 of ''[[Cheers]]'' as Amanda, an acquaintance of [[Diane Chambers]] from the mental institution they both stayed at. Kane was a regular on the 1986 [[NBC]] series ''All Is Forgiven'', a regular on the 1990–91 [[NBC]] series ''[[American Dreamer (television)|American Dreamer]]'', guest-starred on a 1994 episode of ''[[Seinfeld]]’’, a 1996 episode of ‘’[[Ellen]]'' and had a supporting role in the short-lived 1996–97 sitcom ''[[Pearl (TV series)|Pearl]]''. In 1988 Kane appeared in the [[Cinemax Comedy Experiment]] [[Rap Master Ronnie|Rap Master Ronnie: A Report Card]] alongside [[Jon Cryer]] and [[The Smothers Brothers]]. In January 2009, she appeared in the TV series ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'' as the mother of Alan Harper's receptionist.[http://www.tv.com/two-and-a-half-men/thank-god-for-scoliosis/episode/1244269/summary.html Two and a Half Men: Thank God for Scoliosis Season 6"] TV.com. Retrieved August 27, 2011. In March 2010, Kane appeared in the TV series ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' as Justin Suarez's acting teacher. In 2014, she had a recurring role in the TV series ''[[Gotham (TV series)|Gotham]]'' as Gertrude Kapelput, [[Penguin (comics)|Oswald Cobblepot's (Penguin's)]] mother.IMDb.com [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3993368/combined ''Gotham'': "Spirit of the Goat" (episode)]; retrieved October 28, 2014. In 2015, she was cast as Lillian Kaushtupper, the landlord to the title character of [[Netflix]]'s original series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.voxmagazine.com/2015/03/unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-is-a-great-addition-to-netflix-lineup|title=Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt is a great addition to Netflix lineup {{!}} Vox Magazine|work=Vox Magazine|publisher=[[Columbia Missourian]]|last=Havey|first=Max|date=March 20, 2015|accessdate=March 22, 2015}} ===Films=== Kane also appeared in ''[[The Last Detail]]'' (1973), ''[[Annie Hall]]'' (1977), ''[[The World's Greatest Lover]]'' (1977), ''Norman Loves Rose'' (1982), ''[[Dog Day Afternoon]]'' (1975), ''[[Transylvania 6-5000 (1985 film)|Transylvania 6-5000]]'' (1985), ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'' (1987), ''[[Flashback (1990 film)|Flashback]]'' (1989) with [[Dennis Hopper]], and ''[[Scrooged]]'' (1988), in which ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called her "unquestionably [the] pic's comic highlight."[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117794690.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 "Scrooged"] Variety (requires registration). Retrieved August 27, 2011. In 1998, she played Mother Duck on the cartoon movie ''[[The First Snow of Winter]]''. In 1999 she made a cameo on the movie [[Man on the Moon (film)|''Man On The Moon'']] as her character she played on [[Taxi (TV series)|''Taxi'']]. Kane was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] for her role in the film ''[[Hester Street (film)|Hester Street]]''. ===Theatre=== She starred in the [[off-Broadway]] play ''[[Love, Loss, and What I Wore]]'' in February 2010.BWW News Desk.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/LOVE_LOSS_AND_WHAT_I_WORE_Welcomes_Comedic_New_Cast_Janeane_Garofalo_Carol_Kane_More_Bow_23_20091210 " 'Love, Loss And What I Wore' Welcomes Comedic New Cast; Janeane Garofalo, Carol Kane & More Bow 2/3"] broadwayworld.com, December 10, 2009. Kane made her West End debut in January 2011 in a major revival of [[Lillian Hellman]]'s drama ''[[The Children's Hour (play)|The Children's Hour]]'', at London's [[Comedy Theatre]]. She starred alongside [[Keira Knightley]], [[Elisabeth Moss]] and [[Ellen Burstyn]].Shenton, Mark.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/145106-Ellen-Burstyn-and-Carol-Kane-Join-Cast-of-West-Ends-Childrens-Hour Ellen Burstyn and Carol Kane Join Cast of West End's Children's Hour] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018225802/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/145106-Ellen-Burstyn-and-Carol-Kane-Join-Cast-of-West-Ends-Childrens-Hour |date=October 18, 2012 }} Playbill.com, November 19, 2010. In May 2012, Kane appeared on Broadway as Betty Chumley in a revival of the play ''[[Harvey (play)|Harvey]]''. ==== ''Wicked'' ==== Kane is known for her portrayal of the evil headmistress [[Madame Morrible]] in the Broadway musical ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', whom she played in various productions from 2005 to 2014. Kane made her ''Wicked'' debut on the 1st National Tour, playing the role from March 9 through December 19, 2005. She then reprised the role in the Broadway production from January 10 through November 12, 2006. She again played the role for the Los Angeles production which began performances on February 7, 2007. She left the production on December 30, 2007, and later returned from August 26, 2008 until the production closed on January 11, 2009. She then transferred with the L.A. company, to play the role once again, in the San Francisco production which began performances January 27, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/san-francisco/news/12-2008/garrison-kane-kassebaum-wicks-set-for-san-francisc_13504.html|title=Garrison, Kane, Kassebaum, Wicks Set for San Francisco Wicked|author=Dan Bacalzo|date=December 16, 2008}} She ended her limited engagement on March 22, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126830-Academy-Award-Winner-Duke-to-Join-Cast-of-San-Frans-Wicked |title=Academy Award Winner Duke to Join Cast of San Fran's Wicked |author=Andrew Gans |date=March 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105034603/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126830-Academy-Award-Winner-Duke-to-Join-Cast-of-San-Frans-Wicked |archivedate=January 5, 2014 |df= }} Kane returned to the Broadway company of ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'' from July 1, 2013, through February 22, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/179391-Broadways-Wicked-Will-Welcome-Carol-Kane-and-Michael-Wartella |title=Broadway's Wicked Will Welcome Carol Kane and Michael Wartella |date=June 21, 2013 |accessdate=August 30, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829040034/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/179391-Broadways-Wicked-Will-Welcome-Carol-Kane-and-Michael-Wartella |archivedate=August 29, 2013 |df= }} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film and television shows |- ! Let's Be Heroes]]'' | Ginger | Voice; Episode: "One Last Score" |- | 2017 | ''[[Halt and Catch Fire (TV series)|Halt and Catch Fire]] | Denise | Episode: "Ten of Swords" |- | 2017 | ''[[Star vs. the Forces of Evil]]'' | Dr. Jelly Goodwell | Voice; Episode: "Princess Turdina/Starfari" |- | 2018 | ''[[Rapunzel's Tangled Adventure]]'' |Madam Canardist |Voice; Episode: "Vigor the Visionary" |- |2018 | ''[[Animals.]]'' | Chompy | Voice; 2 episodes |- |2018 |''[[The Sisters Brothers (film)|The Sisters Brothers]]'' | Mrs Sisters |Post-production |} ==Other works== * This is My Night (Music Video) (1985) – Mimi in [[Chaka Khan]]'s music video * ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'' (2005–2009; 2013–present) – Madame Morrible (Various productions) == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|1406}} *{{IBDB name}} *{{iobdb name|1760|Carol Kane}} {{Navboxes |title = Awards for Carol Kane |list = {{EmmyAward ComedyLeadActress}} {{EmmyAward ComedySupportingActress}} {{Ohio Women's Hall of Fame}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kane, Carol}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Jewish American actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American musical theatre actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American voice actresses]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Outstanding Performance by a Lead Actress in a Comedy Series Primetime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:Outstanding Performance by a Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series Primetime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:Actresses from Cleveland]] [[Category:Jewish comedians]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]]
